The Neoproterozoic–Cambrian Dalradian Supergroup of Scotland contains three glaciogenic sedimentary units, the Port Askaig Formation, the Stralinchy-Reelan Formation, and the Loch na Cille Boulder Bed, in ascending order. Although the idea, that relatively cold climates occurred during the latest Proterozoic, is widely accepted, the cause of the onset of glaciation is still controversial; we use new carbonate 87Sr/86Sr data to better constrain this environmental change. Some Dalradian limestones have high strontium contents (>1000 ppm), low manganese contents and Mn/Sr ratios (<0.2) and, according to their silica, aluminum and potassium contents and Rb/Sr ratios, they suffered insignificant contamination from siliciclastic minerals, thus they are suitable for estimating the 87Sr/86Sr values of paleoseawater in the Neoproterozoic. The 87Sr/86Sr values of limestones of the Islay Formation (ca. 0.7067), sampled on the island of Islay, are similar to the values of previous studies. However, the 87Sr/86Sr values of limestones just below the Port Askaig Formation (ca. 0.7064), collected on the island of Garbh Eileach, have the lowest values recorded in the Dalradian Supergroup. Comparing these 87Sr/86Sr values with coeval 87Sr/86Sr values of other regions in the world, such low 87Sr/86Sr (<0.7065) has only been reported from successions pre-dating the older Cryogenian (Sturtian) glaciation, which supports the idea that the Port Askaig Formation was deposited during the older Cryogenian glaciation. We have reconstructed the variations in the i87Sr/86Sr ratio from the Tonian through the Cryogenian and Ediacaran to the earliest Cambrian.

The Neoproterozoic to Cambrian Dalradian Supergroup of Scotand was deposited on the eastern margin of Laurentia and contains hree glaciogenic successions, the Port Askaig Formation (Fm), the tralinchy-Reelan Formation, and the Loch na Cille Boulder Bed, n ascending order (Harris et al., 1994; Stephenson and Gould, 995; Condon and Prave, 2000; McCay et al., 2006). The Port Askaig ormation consists of over 700 m of diamictite, conglomerate, sandtone and minor carbonate, and is in the current spotlight due to the xcellent preservation of its sedimentary structures. Although the ge range of most Neoproterozoic successions is poorly constrained y radiometric or biostratigraphic dating, recent lithostratigraphy nd chemostratigraphy have indicated that the Port Askaig Formaion represents the older Cryogenian (Sturtian) glaciation (Prave, 999; Condon and Prave, 2000; McCay et al., 2006; Prave et al., 009). 87Sr/86Sr data are useful to constrain the age of such sedientary sequences (Melezhik et al., 2001; Halverson et al., 2007). rasier and Shields (2000) used the 87Sr/86Sr and 13C of carbonate ediments beneath the Neoproterozoic Dalradian glaciogenic Port skaig Formation to propose an older Cryogenian glacial age for hese carbonates. Thereafter, Thomas et al. (2004), presenting new sotope geochemistry of limestones throughout the entire Neoproerozoic Dalradian, identified secular variations in their 87Sr/86Sr atios.
This work presents new 87Sr/86Sr data from the Dalradian Superroup. There is an unconformity between the Port Askaig Formation nd underlying limestones on Islay (Brasier and Shields, 2000; homas et al., 2004). Therefore, we collected limestone samples on he island of Garbh Eileach (the largest of the Garvellach Islands), here the Port Askaig Formation rests conformably on limestones f the Islay Fm, and we studied the 87Sr/86Sr chemostratigraphy ust below the Port Askaig Formation. Based on our new 87Sr/86Sr ata and their comparison with global 87Sr/86Sr chemostratigraphy hrough the Neoproterozoic, we discuss the environmental changes efore the older Cryogenian glaciation.
. Geology of the Dalradian Supergroup
.1. Geological setting
The Dalradian Supergroup of Scotland consists of siliciclastic nd carbonate sedimentary rocks, together with subordinate volanic rocks that were deposited on continental crust of the eastern argin of Laurentia from the Neoproterozoic to possibly the Midle Cambrian (Anderton, 1982, 1985, 1988; Harris et al., 1994; awood et al., 2003). The Dalradian is divided into four Groups Figs. 1a, b and 2): Grampian (oldest), Appin, Argyll and Southern ighland (youngest). The Grampian Group is dominated by fluvial nd marine siliciclastic sediments and a few limestones (Glover t al., 1995). The relationship between the base of the Grampian roup and gneissose metasedimentary rocks, which may constiute their basement, is unresolved (Smith et al., 1999). The Appin roup consists of a succession of siliciclastic rocks, quartzite and arbonate deposited in a shallow to deep marine environment. he Port Askaig Formation at the base of the Argyll Group mainly omprises a marine glaciogenic succession (Eyles and Eyles, 1983) hat provides a detailed record of changing depositional conditions uring a Neoproterozoic glaciation (Spencer, 1971). The diamicites are interbedded with sandstone, mudstone and conglomerate; he presence of giant cross-beds in the sandstone units indicates epeated ice margin advance and withdrawal, and the influence f strong tidal currents during the glaciation (Arnaud, 2004). depositional environment of the Port Askaig Formation is hotly discussed (e.g. Benn and Prave, 2006) and summarized by Arnaud and Fairchild (in press). Deglaciation was followed by deposition of a thick siliciclastic-dominated sequence of marine deposits and subsequent dolostones: these rocks comprise the Bonahaven Formation. According to Brasier and Shields (2000), the Bonahaven Formation is a cap carbonate, but the presence of sandstones and mudstones below the Bonahaven dolostones indicates that the carbonate does not cap glacial rocks (Arnaud and Fairchild, in press). Although Brasier and Shields (2000) suggested that the negative 13Ccarb values of the Bonahaven dolostones are correlated with those of another cap carbonate sequence (Dracoisen Formation, Svalbard), the negative signature suggests an early marine diagenetic origin (Fairchild and Kennedy, 2007).
Conglomerates at the bottom of the Easdale Subgroup of the Argyll Group may indicate a hiatus of deposition and/or an unconformity (Fig. 2). The middle to upper parts of the Argyll Group are dominated by coarse-grained siliciclastic rocks and limestones that were deposited in rapidly subsiding and relatively deep marine rift basins (Stephenson and Gould, 1995). Recently, McCay et al. (2006) reported a younger Cryogenian (Marinoan)-age glacial deposit in Ireland, the Stralinchy-Reelan Formation, which is composed of diamictite, and the overlying Cranford Limestone contains the characteristic features of a younger Cryogenian glacial-cap carbonate. This glacial-cap carbonate sequence in Ireland is correlated with the Easdale Subgroup in the Dalradian Supergroup (McCay et al., 2006; Prave et al., 2009). Continued subsidence led to deposition of thick turbiditic sandstones of the Southern Highland Group. The Loch na Cille Boulder Bed, the third glacial deposit, constitutes the lower part of this Group and is correlated with the Gaskiers (ca. 580 Ma; Bowring et al., 2003) glacial deposit (McCay et al., 2006). The Leny Limestone of Perthshire, which comprises thin-bedded turbiditic carbonates and contains the Pagetides trilobite fauna, probably belongs to the uppermost part of this Group (Tanner, 1995; Fletcher and Rushton, 2007).
Only four isotopic age data constrain the time of deposition of the Dalradian Supergroup. A U–Pb zircon and monazite age of a pegmatite in a shear zone that truncates the base of the Grampian Group gives minimum ages of 840 ± 11 Ma and 806 ± 3 Ma for the onset of Dalradian sedimentation (Highton et al., 1999; Noble et al., 1996). U–Pb zircon ages from a keratophyre and a felsic tuff in the Tayvallich Volcanic Fm. date the time of volcanism and sedimentation at the top of the Argyll Group at 595 ± 4 Ma and 601 ± 4 Ma, respectively (Halliday et al., 1989; Dempster et al., 2002). These data also provide a lower age limit for deposition of sedimentary rocks of the Argyll Group. Sediments of the Grampian, Appin and Argyll Groups were deposited in the period from 800 to 600 Ma.
2.2. Sampled carbonate units and localities
Winchester (1974) documented the metamorphic grade of the Grampian Highlands and showed that the lower-grade metamorphic facies is in the Southwestern Grampian Highlands (Fig. 1b). Because metamorphism and alteration are unfavorable for preservation of carbonate primary 87Sr/86Sr, we collected samples in the better-preserved rocks on the Garbh Eileach and Islay Islands (Fig. 1), on both of which we produced a stratigraphic column (Figs. 3 and 4).
At Beannan Dubh on Islay (Fig. 1c) we collected rock samples from the Blair Atholl Subgroup and the Port Askaig Formation. The beds of carbonate and sandstone in this area strike NE–SW and dip NW (Fig. 1c). The Blair Atholl Subgroup comprises two carbonate units; the lower is the Ballygrant Fm and the upper is the Islay Fm (Fig. 3). The chemical and isotopic compositions are summarized in able 2 and Figs. 6 and 7.
.1. Post-depositional alteration
The isotopic composition of Sr in marine carbonates is suseptible to alteration, the processes of which may include early iagenetic transformations and late diagenetic fluid reaction. Altertion through interaction with clay minerals and groundwater with adiogenic isotopic compositions would increase 87Sr/86Sr ratios, hereas interaction with fluids from a juvenile volcanic source ould decrease them.

Previous workers cited 18O-depletion, a low strontium content, a very high manganese content, a high Mn/Sr ratio, a relationship between Sr/Ca and Mn content and a conjugate decrease of 13C and 18O, as characteristics of diagenetic alteration by meteoric water (Brand and Veizer, 1980, 1981; Banner and Hanson, 1990; Jacobsen and Kaufman, 1999; Halverson et al., 2007; Sawaki et al., 2008). In our study, we have checked the Mn/Sr ratio, the strontium content, 18O and the relationship between the Sr/Ca ratio and the manganese content. A detailed investigation of the relationship between the Sr/Ca ratio and manganese content in our carbonate rocks indicates that rocks with higher manganese contents have lower Sr/Ca ratios (Fig. 6). Rock samples with low manganese contents and a high Sr/Ca ratio are suitable for preservation of primary 87Sr/86Sr values (Brand and Veizer, 1980, 1981).
The Mn/Sr ratio is often used in the discrimination of diagenetic alterations, and the maximum Mn/Sr ratio of apparently unaltered samples ranges from 1 to 3 (Kaufman et al., 1993; Brasier et al., 1996; Kennedy et al., 1998; Jacobsen and Kaufman, 1999). Thomas et al. (2004), who also studied Dalradian carbonates, used Mn/Sr <0.2 to discriminate between unaltered and altered rocks. In our GE and ISS samples, we identify positive correlations between the 87Sr/86Sr and Mn/Sr ratios and a negative correlation between 87Sr/86Sr and the strontium content (Fig. 6). It is commonly thought that rocks with a low Mn/Sr ratio and high strontium content preserve primary 87Sr/86Sr values (e.g. Kaufman et al., 1993). Consequently, we selected limestones with Mn/Sr <0.2 as the least altered. This criterion is the same as in previous works (Fairchild et al., 2000; Thomas et al., 2004). These carbonate rocks have very high strontium contents (>1000 ppm), and the 18O ratios of samples with a low Mn/Sr ratio (<0.2) are not noticeably low. We suggest that these sixteen carbonate samples (GE1, 2, 23, 24, 25, 26 and 27 and ISS14, 15, 17, 22, 26, 27, 32, 36 and 47) preserve primary 87Sr/86Sr ratios.
4.2. Influence of detrital components
Involvement of detrital materials influences Sr isotope compositions, because terrigenous detritus has radiogenic Sr isotopic compositions. In particular, the involvement of clay minerals and feldspars originating from continental crust can significantly increase the 87Sr/86Sr ratios, because of their high Sr contents. Because clay minerals and feldspars also have higher Al, Si, K and Rb contents than carbonate minerals, we checked the correlation between 87Sr/86Sr ratios and Al, Si, K and Rb contents in order to estimate the influence of detrital components.
There are no correlations between 87Sr/86Sr ratios and Al, Si, K and Rb contents in the samples of the ISS and GE limestone of the Islay Fm, indicating minimal influence and involvement of clay minerals and feldspar on the 87Sr/86Sr (Fig. 7). In addition, previous workers suggested a threshold of Rb/Sr <0.001–0.01 to diagnose unaltered and detritus-free samples (Derry et al., 1989; Asmerom et al., 1991; Kaufman et al., 1993). Our samples with low Mn/Sr ratios (<0.2) also have very low (<0.003) Rb/Sr ratios, suggesting that detrital components were not effective in influencing the 87Sr/86Sr ratios of these carbonates.

. Conclusions
We present new 87Sr/86Sr data from carbonates below the ort Askaig Formation in the Dalradian Supergroup. The values of 7Sr/86Sr of the Ballygrant Fm and the Islay Fm on Islay are simlar to the corresponding values of previous studies. The values f 87Sr/86Sr of the Islay Fm on Garbh Eileach are lower than the alues of previous studies and correspond to the values between he Port Askaig Formation and the Islay Fm of earlier studies. On slay the contact between the Islay Fm and the overlying Port skaig Formation is erosive, whereas on Garbh Eileach the conact between them does not appear to be a major hiatus. Compared with the 87Sr/86Sr excursion in other reas worldwide, such low values are only reported before the lder Cryogenian glaciation (Sturtian) in the Neoproterozoic. abstractText: The Neoproterozoic–Cambrian Dalradian Supergroup of Scotland contains three glaciogenic sedimentary units, the Port Askaig Formation, the Stralinchy-Reelan Formation, and the Loch na Cille Boulder Bed, in ascending order. Although the idea, that relatively cold climates occurred during the latest Proterozoic, is widely accepted, the cause of the onset of glaciation is still controversial; we use new carbonate 87Sr/86Sr data to better constrain this environmental change. Some Dalradian limestones have high strontium contents (>1000 ppm), low manganese contents and Mn/Sr ratios (<0.2) and, according to their silica, aluminum and potassium contents and Rb/Sr ratios, they suffered insignificant contamination from siliciclastic minerals, thus they are suitable for estimating the 87Sr/86Sr values of paleoseawater in the Neoproterozoic. The 87Sr/86Sr values of limestones of the Islay Formation (ca. 0.7067), sampled on the island of Islay, are similar to the values of previous studies. However, the 87Sr/86Sr values of limestones just below the Port Askaig Formation (ca. 0.7064), collected on the island of Garbh Eileach, have the lowest values recorded in the Dalradian Supergroup. Comparing these 87Sr/86Sr values with coeval 87Sr/86Sr values of other regions in the world, such low 87Sr/86Sr (<0.7065) has only been reported from successions pre-dating the older Cryogenian (Sturtian) glaciation, which supports the idea that the Port Askaig Formation was deposited during the older Cryogenian glaciation.
